hints_html: This is a routine induction problem. You might want to use the fact that \(12^2 = 144 = 133 + 11\)
hints_latex:
This is a routine induction problem. You might want to use the fact that
$12^2 = 144 = 133 + 11$
hints_raw: This is a routine induction problem. You might want to use the fact that <math>12^2 = 144 = 133 + 11 </math>
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
First, we prove the claim true when \(n = 1\). In this case,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 12^{2n-1} + 11^{n+1} = 12^{2(1)-1} + 11^{1+1} = 12 + 121 = 133\end{aligned}\]

which is clearly divisible by 133. We assume the claim is true for \(n=k\). For \(n = k +1\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} 12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1} &= 12^{2k+1} + 11^{k+2}\\ &= 12^{2}\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\ &= 144\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\ &= (133+11)12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\ &= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\ &= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11(12^{2k-1} + 11^{k+1})\end{aligned}\]

Now, in the last line, the first summand is divisible by 133 and the second summand is also divisible by 133 by the induction hypothesis. Hence we must have that \(12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1}\) is divisible by 133 as required.
sols_latex:
First, we prove the claim true when $n = 1$. In this case,

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 12^{2n-1} + 11^{n+1} = 12^{2(1)-1} + 11^{1+1} = 12 + 121 = 133
\end{align*}

which is clearly divisible by 133. We assume the claim is true for
$n=k$. For $n = k +1$, we have

\begin{align*}
12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1} &= 12^{2k+1} + 11^{k+2}\\
&= 12^{2}\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 144\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= (133+11)12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11(12^{2k-1} + 11^{k+1})
\end{align*}

Now, in the last line, the first summand is divisible by 133 and the
second summand is also divisible by 133 by the induction hypothesis.
Hence we must have that $12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1}$ is divisible by
133 as required.
sols_raw:
First, we prove the claim true when <math> n = 1 </math>. In this case,

:<math>
\displaystyle 12^{2n-1} + 11^{n+1} = 12^{2(1)-1} + 11^{1+1} = 12 + 121 = 133
</math>

which is clearly divisible by 133. We assume the claim is true for <math> n=k </math>. For <math> n = k +1 </math>, we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1} &= 12^{2k+1} + 11^{k+2}\\
&= 12^{2}\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 144\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= (133+11)12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11\cdot12^{2k-1} + 11\cdot 11^{k+1}\\
&= 133\cdot12^{2k-1}+11(12^{2k-1} + 11^{k+1})
\end{align}
</math>

Now, in the last line, the first summand is divisible by 133 and the second summand is also divisible by 133 by the induction hypothesis. Hence we must have that <math> 12^{2(k+1)-1} + 11^{(k+1)+1} </math> is divisible by 133 as required.
statement_html:
Use mathematical induction to prove the following statement:

\[\begin{aligned} \text{For all }n \in \mathbb{N}, 12^{2n-1} + 11^{n+1} \,\text{is a multiple of 133.}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Use mathematical induction to prove the following statement:

:<math>
\text{For all }n \in \mathbb{N}, 12^{2n-1} + 11^{n+1} \,\text{ is a multiple of 133.}
</math>
